facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 67 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 67 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 18, 1968 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 407 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 18, 1968 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 407 of 1966.

facts.text: Patna High Court upheld the conviction of the appellant under s. 411 of the Indian Penal Code with sentence of three years rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: from a judgment of the Patna High Court upholding the companyviction of the appellant under s. 411 of the Indian Penal Code for which a sentence of three years rigorous imprisonment was imposed.

facts.text: A Sen-Raleigh cycle was stolen from the possession of Sheo Charan Lal.

anchor.surface_text: According to the case of the prosecution a Sen-Raleigh cycle was stolen from the possession of Sheo Charan Lal.

facts.text: Sheo Charan Lal reported the theft to the Police on March 25, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: He reported the matter to the Police on March 25, 1965.

facts.text: The Sen-Raleigh cycle was stolen on March 24, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: the Sen-Raleigh cycle belonging to Sheo Charan Lal which was stolen on March 24, 1965

facts.text: On May 11, 1965, Station House Officer A.D.N. Sinha learnt that a thief was running away with a cycle on Moharram day.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on May 11, 1965 the Station House Officer, Incharge Giridih Police Station A.D.N, Sinha learnt while he was moving about in the town on the Moharram day that a thief was running away with a Sycle.

facts.text: Mohd. Siddique was apprehended with a cycle in his possession on May 11, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The alleged thief was apprehended and the cycle in his possession was taken into custody. The name of that person was Mohnd. Siddique.

facts.text: Mohd. Siddique made a statement to the police officer which led to search of appellant's premises.

anchor.surface_text: He made, a statement to the police officer which led him to search the premises of the appellant.

facts.text: Seven cycles including the Sen-Raleigh cycle belonging to Sheo Charan Lal and three other cycles were recovered from the house of the appellant on May 11, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the search seven cycles including the Sen-Raleigh cycle belonging to Sheo Charan Lal which was stolen on March 24, 1965 and three other cycles were recovered from the house of the appellant,

facts.text: Mohd. Siddique and the appellant were tried; Siddique under s. 379 IPC and appellant under s. 411 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Mohd, Siddique and the appellant were tried, the former under s. 379 and the latter under s. 411 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Siddique was convicted and sentenced but did not file any appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Siddique was companyvicted and sentenced but he did number file any appeal.

facts.text: It was not disputed that the Sen-Raleigh cycle was recovered along with nine other cycles from the appellant's house by D.N. Sinha on May 11, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: It was number disputed before the High Court that the Sen- Raleigh. cycle was recovered along with nine other cycles as a result of the search of the house of the appellant by D.N. Sinha the S.H.O. on May 11, 1965.

facts.text: It was proved that the Sen-Raleigh cycle was stolen.

anchor.surface_text: It was also proved that that cycle was stolen.

facts.text: Appellant claimed three out of the 10 cycles belonged to family members and seven pledged as pawn broker.

anchor.surface_text: The explanation given by the appellant was that three out of the 10 cycles belonged to the members of his family and the other seven had been pledged with him as he carried on the business of a pawn broker.

facts.text: Appellant claimed Sen-Raleigh cycle pledged by Siddique.

anchor.surface_text: The Sen-Raleigh cycle had been pledged by Siddique with him and that is how the said cycle was recovered from his possession.

facts.text: PW1 Jayantilal and PW2 Shyam Narain Singh deposed that appellant and family lived in same house.

anchor.surface_text: P.W. I Jayantilal and P.W. 2 Shyam Narain, Singh deposed that the appellant as well as his brothers and other members of his family lived in the same house.

facts.text: Appellant and brothers worked as contractors and took things on pawn, advanced money.

anchor.surface_text: It was further stated by them that the appellant and his brothers worked as companytractors and they also took things on pawn and advanced money.

facts.text: Shyam Narain Singh saw ornaments and utensils pledged but not cycles.

anchor.surface_text: According to Shyam Narain Singh he had seen ornaments and utensils being taken on pledge by the appellant and members of his family although he had number seen him taking any cycle on pledge.

facts.text: Appellant produced document Exh.DA scribed by Baldev Pandit, attested by witnesses, stating Rs.80 advance from appellant to Siddique and cycle pledged.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant also produced a document Exh.DA which was scribed by one Baldev Pandit and had been attested by some witnesses. In this document it was stand that Rs. 80 bad been received by Siddique by way of advance from the appellant and that the cycle in question had been pledged with the latter.

facts.text: Scribe Baldev Pandit and attesting witnesses Mahabir Sao and Nanden did not give evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Neither the scribe number Mahabir Sao or Nanden who were the attesting witnesses gave evidence.

facts.text: DW1 Ramjit Sao deposed that Exh.A scribed in his presence, Rs.80 paid to Siddique for pawned cycle.

anchor.surface_text: D.W. I Ramjit Sao a neighbour deposed that the document Exh.A had been scribed in his presence and that Rs. 80/- had been paid to Siddique. Siddique had pawned the cycle by way of security for the advance.

facts.text: Courts below found document manufactured, not genuine.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrts below found that this document had been manufactured for the purpose. of the case implying thereby that it was number genuine.

facts.text: Appellant produced no evidence about pledging of other cycles or other pledged articles during search.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant does number appear to have produced any evidence about the pledging of the other cycles which were found in his possession number did he point to any other article apart from the cycles which had been pledged with him in the companyrse of his business when the, search was made of his house by the S.H.O. A.D. N. Sinha.

facts.text: High Court considered no proper enquiries about cycle ownership by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Although two defence witnesses had been examined by the appellant there was numberhing to show that he had taken the ordinary precaution of making proper enquiries about the ownership of the cycle before advancing any loan on its security.

facts.text: Document Exh.A silent on source of cycle by Siddique.

anchor.surface_text: It was significant that the document Exh. A was quite silent as to the source from where Siddique had got that cycle and when he had acquired it.

facts.text: Investigating Officer verified from police records that besides Sen-Raleigh, cases instituted for four more recovered cycles.

anchor.surface_text: The Investigating Officer had deposed to the fact that after the recovery of 10 cycles he made a verification from the records of the Police station and found that besides the Sen-Raleigh cycle cases had been instituted earlier with respect to four more cycles out of the recovered cycles.

facts.text: At least two cycles recovered from appellant admitted by Siddique as stolen by him.

anchor.surface_text: Even if it be assumed that this evidence was number admissible according to the charge as framed with regard to two cycles the same had been recovered from the place of the appellant which had been admitted by Siddique as having been stolen by him.

facts.text: Supreme Court found explanation not reasonably true, drew presumption under s.114(a) Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: we are unable to companye, to the companyclusion that the explanation companyld be regarded such as might reasonably be true. ... A presumption, therefore, companyld immediately be drawn in accordance with S. 114, Illustration  a  of the Evidence Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court maintained conviction and sentence, dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the companyviction and the sentence of the appellant are maintained and the appeal is dismissed.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 18, 1968 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 407 of 1966.

This is an appeal by special leave from a judgment of the Patna High Court upholding the conviction of the appellant under s. 411 of the Indian Penal Code for which a sentence of three years rigorous imprisonment was imposed.

under s. 411 of the Indian Penal Code for which a sentence of three years rigorous imprisonment was imposed. According to the case of the prosecution a Sen-Raleigh cycle was stolen from the possession of Sheo Charan Lal.

anchor.surface_text: Mohd, Siddique and the appellant were tried, the former under s. 379 and the latter under s. 411 of the Indian Penal Code.

the correct ambit and scope of the presumption which can be drawn under s. 114, illustration a of the Evidence Act was not considered by the High Court or the courts below. Section 114 provides that the court may presume the existence of any fact which it thinks likely to have happened regard being had to the common course of natural events, human conduct and public and private business, in their relation to facts of the particular case. Illustration a is as follows that a person who is in possession of stolen property soon after the theft is either the thief or has received the goods knowing that to be stolen unless he can account for his possession.

concepts.interpretation: Presumption arises if explanation for possession of recently stolen property is not such as might reasonably be true.

anchor.surface_text: A presumption, therefore, could immediately be drawn in accordance with S. 114, Illustration a of the Evidence Act. There was hardly any evidence worth the name by which it could be said that the presumption had been rebutted by the appellant.

concepts.interpretation: Explanation given by appellant not reasonably true, so presumption of guilty knowledge drawn and not rebutted.

anchor.surface_text: if an explanation were given which the jury think might reasonably be true, and which is consistent with innocence although they were not convinced of its truth the prisoners were entitled to be acquitted inasmuch as the prosecution would have failed to discharge the duty cast upon it of satisfying the jury beyond reasonable doubt of the guilt of the accused.

concepts.interpretation: Prosecution must prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt; reasonable explanation rebuts presumption even if not fully believed.

concepts.unlisted_description: Standard of proof in criminal cases

anchor.surface_text: In Otto George Gfeller v. The King the law as enunciated in Rex v. Abramovitch was accepted as representing the correct statement on the subject of the presumption to be drawn in such cases. That was in the following terms Upon the prosecution establishing that the accused were in possession of goods recently stolen they may in the absence of any explanation by the accused of the way in which the goods came into their possession which might reasonably be true find them guilty, but that if an explanation were given which the jury think might reasonably be true, and which is consistent with innocence although they were not convinced of its truth the prisoners were entitled to be acquitted

concepts.interpretation: Explanation for possession must be one that might reasonably be true to rebut presumption under Evidence Act s.114(a); appellant's explanation held not reasonably true.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: onably- be true even though the companyrts were number companyvinced of its truth. Since the companyrts below and the, High Court have taken some irre

concepts.unlisted_description: Test to rebut presumption of guilty reception of stolen property

anchor.surface_text: We may in this connection refer to a judgment of Lord Widgery C.J. in Atwal v. Massey in which it was laid down that in order to establish an offence under s. 22 of the English Theft Act 1968 which is similar in terms to s. 411 of the Indian Penal Code, it was not sufficient to show that the goods had been received in circumstances which would have put a reasonable man on enquiry the question was a subjective one was the appellant aware of the theft or did he believe the goods to be stolen or did he, suspecting the goods to be stolen, deliberately shut his eyes to the circumstances ?

concepts.interpretation: For offence similar to s.411 IPC, mens rea is subjective awareness, belief, or wilful blindness, not merely circumstances putting reasonable man on enquiry.

issues.text: Whether the prosecution relating to the other cycles should have been taken into account when the trial was confined to the alleged theft of the Sen-Raleigh cycle and its receipt by the appellant under s.411 IPC?

anchor.surface_text: guilty of an offence under s. 411 of the Indian Penal Code the prosecution relating to the other cycles should not have been taken into account. It has next been urged that the whole approach with regard to the appellant not having made bona fide enquiry from Siddique before accepting the Sen-Raleigh cycle in pledge was unsustainable in law.

issues.text: Whether to establish an offence under s.411 IPC (similar to English Theft Act s.22) it is sufficient to show receipt in circumstances putting a reasonable man on enquiry, or whether a subjective test of awareness, belief or wilful blindness is required?

anchor.surface_text: We may in this connection refer to a judgment of Lord Widgery C.J. in Atwal v. Massey in which it was laid down that in order to establish an offence under s. 22 of the English Theft Act 1968 which is similar in terms to s. 411 of the Indian Penal Code, it was not sufficient to show that the goods had been received in circumstances which would have put a reasonable man on enquiry the question was a subjective one was the appellant aware of the theft or did he believe the goods to be stolen or did he, suspecting the goods to be stolen, deliberately shut his eyes to the circumstances ?

issues.text: What is the correct ambit and scope of the presumption which can be drawn under s.114 illustration (a) of the Evidence Act?

anchor.surface_text: the correct ambit and scope of the presumption which can be drawn under s. 114, illustration a of the Evidence Act was not considered by the High Court or the courts below. Section 114 provides that the court may presume the existence of any fact which it thinks likely to have happened regard being had to the common course of natural events, human conduct and public and private business, in their relation to facts of the particular case.

issues.text: Whether the explanation given by the appellant as to how he came into possession of the Sen-Raleigh cycle might reasonably be true (consistent with innocence), even if not fully convincing, so as to rebut the presumption under s.114(a) Evidence Act and entitle him to acquittal?

anchor.surface_text: The question that the courts, therefore, had to decide was whether the explanation given by the appellant in view of the admission that the Sen-Raleigh cycle was stolen property could be held to fall within the above rule, namely, whether it might reasonably- be true even though the courts were not convinced of its truth.

arguments.claim: Appellant's explanation cannot be regarded as reasonably true; presumption under s.114(a) Evidence Act arises and not rebutted

arguments.claim: Document Exh.DA not proved; no other pledged articles or accounts maintained, contrary to normal pawn broker practice

anchor.surface_text: The first and the most important fact is that the appellant had sought to prove the document ext. DA to support the transaction of pledge. That document bad rightly been found not to have been proved. Apart from the Sen-Raleigh cycle several other cycles were found in the possession of the appellant which he claimed to have been pledged with him. No articles of any other kind were either pointed out or claimed to have been pledged with the appellant or with members of his family which would normally have been done if the version given by him that the business of pawn brokers was being carried on had any truth in it.

holdings.text: The explanation given by the appellant could not be regarded as one that might reasonably be true.

anchor.surface_text: we are unable to companye, to the companyclusion that the explanation companyld be regarded such as might reasonably be true. ... A presumption, therefore, companyld immediately be drawn in accordance with S. 114, Illustration  a  of the Evidence Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Independent examination of facts: document Exh. DA not proved, no other pledged articles or accounts produced contrary to normal pawn broker practice, no enquiries about ownership.

holdings.text: A presumption could immediately be drawn under Section 114 Illustration (a) of the Evidence Act that the appellant received the stolen property knowing it to be stolen.

anchor.surface_text: A presumption, therefore, companyld immediately be drawn in accordance with S. 114, Illustration a of the Evidence Act. There was hardly any evidence worth the name by which it companyld be said that the presumption had been rebutted by the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Possession of stolen property soon after theft; explanation fails 'might reasonably be true' test from precedents like Otto George Gfeller v. The King and Rex v. Abramovitch.

holdings.text: The presumption under Section 114 Illustration (a) was not rebutted by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: There was hardly any evidence worth the name by which it companyld be said that the presumption had been rebutted by the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No credible evidence to displace presumption after it arose; lack of supporting proof for pawn transaction.

holdings.text: Even assuming evidence regarding other cycles inadmissible, the conviction under s.411 IPC is sustainable.

anchor.surface_text: Even if it be assumed that this evidence was number admissible according to the charge as framed with regard to two cycles the same had been recovered from the place of the appellant which had been admitted by Siddique as having been stolen by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: At least two cycles admitted stolen; combined with other circumstances like lack of bona fides in transaction, supports guilty knowledge without needing other cycles prosecution.

holdings.text: The conviction of the appellant under s.411 IPC and sentence of three years rigorous imprisonment are maintained; appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the companyviction and the sentence of the appellant are maintained and the appeal is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explanation rejected, presumption of guilty reception of stolen property drawn and unrebutted, satisfying proof beyond reasonable doubt.
